parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The identifier of the Collection receiving the Tweet.

parameters.name: tweet_id
parameters.description: The identifier of the Tweet to add to the Collection.

parameters.name: relative_to
parameters.description: The identifier of the Tweet used for relative positioning.

parameters.name: above
parameters.description: Set to false to insert the specified tweet_id below the relative_to Tweet in the collection. Default: true

parameters.name: force_login
parameters.description: Forces the user to enter their credentials to ensure the correct users account is authorized.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: Prefills the username input box of the OAuth login screen with the given value.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen_name of the user to report as a spammer. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user to report as a spammer. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: perform_block
parameters.description: Whether the account should be blocked by the authenticated user, as well as being reported for spam.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: (required) The id of the Welcome Message Rule that should be deleted.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the results to be broken into pages. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of users to return per page, up to a maximum of 200. Defaults to 20.

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , statuses will not be included in the returned user objects. If set to any other value, statuses will be included.

parameters.name: include_user_entities
parameters.description: The user object entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of Tweets to try and retrieve, up to a maximum of 200. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied. We include retweets in the count, even if include_rts is not supplied. It is recommended you always send include_rts=1 when using this API method.

parameters.name: since_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

parameters.name: max_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

parameters.name: trim_user
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: sleep_time_enabled
parameters.description: When set to true , t or 1 , will enable sleep time for the user. Sleep time is the time when push or SMS notifications should not be sent to the user.

parameters.name: start_sleep_time
parameters.description: The hour that sleep time should begin if it is enabled. The value for this parameter should be provided in ISO 8601 format (i.e. 00-23). The time is considered to be in the same timezone as the user’s time_zone setting.

parameters.name: end_sleep_time
parameters.description: The hour that sleep time should end if it is enabled. The value for this parameter should be provided in ISO 8601 format (i.e. 00-23). The time is considered to be in the same timezone as the user’s time_zone setting.

parameters.name: time_zone
parameters.description: The timezone dates and times should be displayed in for the user. The timezone must be one of the Rails TimeZone names.

parameters.name: trend_location_woeid
parameters.description:
The Yahoo! Where On Earth ID to use as the user’s default trend location. Global information is available by using 1 as the WOEID. The WOEID must be one of the locations returned by ` GET trends/available
</en/docs/trends/locations-with-trending-topics/api-reference/get-trends-available>`__ .

parameters.name: lang
parameters.description: The language which Twitter should render in for this user. The language must be specified by the appropriate two letter ISO 639-1 representation. Currently supported languages are provided by this endpoint .

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the saved search.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: (optional) Number of welcome messages to be returned. Max of 50. Default is 20.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: (optional) For paging through result sets greater than 1 page, use the “next_cursor” property from the previous request.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The amount of results to return per page. Defaults to 20. No more than 1000 results will ever be returned in a single page.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: Breaks the results into pages. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body’s next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list. It is recommended to always use cursors when the method supports them. See Cursoring for more information.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: (required) Encoded URL for the callback endpoint.

parameters.name: list_id
parameters.description: The numerical id of the list.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: You can identify a list by its slug instead of its numerical id. If you decide to do so, note that you’ll also have to specify the list owner using the owner_id or owner_screen_name parameters.

parameters.name: owner_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The user ID of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of results to return per page (see cursor below). The default is 20, with a maximum of 5,000.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the collection of list members to be broken into “pages” of consistent sizes (specified by the count parameter). If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: list_id
parameters.description: The numerical id of the list.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: You can identify a list by its slug instead of its numerical id. If you decide to do so, note that you’ll also have to specify the list owner using the owner_id or owner_screen_name parameters.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: A comma separated list of user IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: A comma separated list of screen names, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: owner_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The user ID of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the potentially muted user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the potentially muted user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: (optional) Number of welcome message rules to be returned. Max of 50. Default is 20.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: (optional) For paging through result sets greater than 1 page, use the “next_cursor” property from the previous request.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: (required) The id of the Welcome Message that should be returned.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The numerical ID of the desired status.

parameters.name: trim_user
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

parameters.name: list_id
parameters.description: The numerical id of the list.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: You can identify a list by its slug instead of its numerical id. If you decide to do so, note that you’ll also have to specify the list owner using the owner_id or owner_screen_name parameters.

parameters.name: owner_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The user ID of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of connections to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Some programming environments will not consume Twitter IDs due to their size. Provide this option to have IDs returned as strings instead. More about Twitter IDs .

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of IDs attempt retrieval of, up to a maximum of 5,000 per distinct request. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of results to return. When using the count parameter with this method, it is wise to use a consistent count value across all requests to the same user’s collection. Usage of this parameter is encouraged in environments where all 5,000 IDs constitutes too large of a response.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: The short name of list or a category

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The identifier of the Collection to modify.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The title of the Collection being created, in 25 characters or fewer.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A brief description of this Collection in 160 characters or fewer.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: A fully-qualified URL to associate with this Collection.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of connections to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Many programming environments will not consume our Tweet ids due to their size. Provide this option to have ids returned as strings instead.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: A comma separated list of screen names, up to 100 are allowed in a single request. You are strongly encouraged to use a POST for larger (up to 100 screen names) requests.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: A comma separated list of user IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request. You are strongly encouraged to use a POST for larger requests.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node that may appear within embedded statuses will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Full name associated with the profile.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: URL associated with the profile. Will be prepended with “ http:// ” if not present.

parameters.name: location
parameters.description: The city or country describing where the user of the account is located. The contents are not normalized or geocoded in any way.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A description of the user owning the account.

parameters.name: profile_link_color
parameters.description: Sets a hex value that controls the color scheme of links used on the authenticating user’s profile page on twitter.com. This must be a valid hexadecimal value, and may be either three or six characters (ex: F00 or FF0000). This parameter replaces the deprecated (and separate) update_profile_colors API method.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user object.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The numerical ID of the desired status.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of records to retrieve. Must be less than or equal to 100.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of IDs to be broken into pages of no more than 100 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 100 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See our cursor docs for more information.

While this method supports the cursor parameter, the entire result set can be returned in a single cursored collection. Using the count parameter with this method will not provide segmented cursors for use with this parameter.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Many programming environments will not consume Tweet ids due to their size. Provide this option to have ids returned as strings instead.

parameters.name: since_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

parameters.name: max_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of direct messages to try and retrieve, up to a maximum of 200. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of Tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: A comma separated list of screen names, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: A comma separated list of user IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The amount of results to return per page. Defaults to 20. No more than 1000 results will ever be returned in a single page.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: Breaks the results into pages. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body’s next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list. It is recommended to always use cursors when the method supports them. See Cursoring for more information.

parameters.name: filter_to_owned_lists
parameters.description: When set to true , t or 1 , will return just lists the authenticating user owns, and the user represented by user_id or screen_name is a member of.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: A UTF-8, URL-encoded search query of 500 characters maximum, including operators. Queries may additionally be limited by complexity.

parameters.name: geocode
parameters.description: Returns tweets by users located within a given radius of the given latitude/longitude. The location is preferentially taking from the Geotagging API, but will fall back to their Twitter profile. The parameter value is specified by ” latitude,longitude,radius ”, where radius units must be specified as either ” mi ” (miles) or ” km ” (kilometers). Note that you cannot use the near operator via the API to geocode arbitrary locations; however you can use this geocode parameter to search near geocodes directly. A maximum of 1,000 distinct “sub-regions” will be considered when using the radius modifier.

parameters.name: lang
parameters.description: Restricts tweets to the given language, given by an ISO 639-1 code. Language detection is best-effort.

parameters.name: locale
parameters.description: Specify the language of the query you are sending (only ja is currently effective). This is intended for language-specific consumers and the default should work in the majority of cases.

parameters.name: result_type
parameters.description:
Optional. Specifies what type of search results you would prefer to receive. The current default is “mixed.” Valid values include:

* mixed : Include both popular and real time results in the response.

* recent : return only the most recent results in the response

* popular : return only the most popular results in the response.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of tweets to return per page, up to a maximum of 100. Defaults to 15. This was formerly the “rpp” parameter in the old Search API.

parameters.name: until
parameters.description: Returns tweets created before the given date. Date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD. Keep in mind that the search index has a 7-day limit. In other words, no tweets will be found for a date older than one week.

parameters.name: since_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

parameters.name: max_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: owner_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The user ID of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.description: The numerical id of the list.

parameters.description: The screen name of the user who should receive the Direct Message. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text of your Direct Message. Be sure to URL encode as necessary.

If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each Tweet will include a node called “entities”. This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See Tweet Entities for more details.

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: The avatar image for the profile, base64-encoded. Must be a valid GIF, JPG, or PNG image of less than 700 kilobytes in size. Images with width larger than 400 pixels will be scaled down. Animated GIFs will be converted to a static GIF of the first frame, removing the animation.

parameters.name: include_my_retweet
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , any Tweets returned that have been retweeted by the authenticating user will include an additional current_user_retweet node, containing the ID of the source status for the retweet.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: include_ext_alt_text
parameters.description: If alt text has been added to any attached media entities, this parameter will return an ext_alt_text value in the top-level key for the media entity. If no value has been set, this will be returned as null

parameters.name: id

parameters.name: place_id
parameters.description: A place in the world. These IDs can be retrieved from geo/reverse_geocode.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the direct message to delete.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: The background image for the profile, base64-encoded. Must be a valid GIF, JPG, or PNG image of less than 800 kilobytes in size. Images with width larger than 2048 pixels will be forcibly scaled down. The image must be provided as raw multipart data, not a URL.

parameters.name: tile
parameters.description: Whether or not to tile the background image. If set to true , t or 1 the background image will be displayed tiled. The image will not be tiled otherwise.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: media_id
parameters.description: Specify the media to use as the background image. More information on upload of media is available here .

parameters.name: webhook_id
parameters.description: (required) Webhook ID. Defined in resource path.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Whether your list is public or private. Values can be public or private . If no mode is specified the list will be public.

If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of Tweets to try and retrieve, up to a maximum of 200 per distinct request. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of Tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied. We include retweets in the count, even if include_rts is not supplied. It is recommended you always send include_rts=1 when using this API method.

parameters.name: max_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

parameters.name: trim_user
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each Tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

parameters.name: exclude_replies
parameters.description: This parameter will prevent replies from appearing in the returned timeline. Using exclude_replies with the count parameter will mean you will receive up-to count tweets — this is because the count parameter retrieves that many Tweets before filtering out retweets and replies.

parameters.name: include_rts
parameters.description: When set to false , the timeline will strip any native retweets (though they will still count toward both the maximal length of the timeline and the slice selected by the count parameter). Note: If you’re using the trim_user parameter in conjunction with include_rts, the retweets will still contain a full user object.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Many programming environments will not consume Twitter IDs due to their size. Provide this option to have IDs returned as strings instead. Read more about Twitter IDs .

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of IDs to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results. Either an id or screen_name is required for this method.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results. Either a id or screen_name is required for this method.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of blocked users to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: The short name of list or a category

parameters.name: lang
parameters.description: Restricts the suggested categories to the requested language. The language must be specified by the appropriate two letter ISO 639-1 representation. Currently supported languages are provided by the `GET help/languages`_ API request. Unsupported language codes will receive English (en) results. If you use lang in this request, ensure you also include it when requesting the GET users/suggestions/:slug list.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The numerical ID of the Tweet to like.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will be omitted when set to false .

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: The query of the search the user would like to save.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the direct message.

parameters.name: list_id
parameters.description: The numerical id of the list.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: You can identify a list by its slug instead of its numerical id. If you decide to do so, note that you’ll also have to specify the list owner using the owner_id or owner_screen_name parameters.

parameters.name: owner_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The user ID of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: since_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

parameters.name: max_id
parameters.description: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the number of results to retrieve per “page.”

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: Entities are ON by default in API 1.1, each tweet includes a node called “entities”. This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. You can omit entities from the result by using include_entities=false

parameters.name: include_rts
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , the list timeline will contain native retweets (if they exist) in addition to the standard stream of tweets. The output format of retweeted tweets is identical to the representation you see in home_timeline.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: The text of the status update. URL encode as necessary. t.co link wrapping will affect character counts.

parameters.name: in_reply_to_status_id
parameters.description: The ID of an existing status that the update is in reply to. Note: This parameter will be ignored unless the author of the Tweet this parameter references is mentioned within the status text. Therefore, you must include @username , where username is the author of the referenced Tweet, within the update.

parameters.name: auto_populate_reply_metadata
parameters.description: If set to true and used with in_reply_to_status_id , leading @mentions will be looked up from the original Tweet, and added to the new Tweet from there. This wil append @mentions into the metadata of an extended Tweet as a reply chain grows, until the limit on @mentions is reached. In cases where the original Tweet has been deleted, the reply will fail.

parameters.name: exclude_reply_user_ids
parameters.description: When used with auto_populate_reply_metadata , a comma-separated list of user ids which will be removed from the server-generated @mentions prefix on an extended Tweet. Note that the leading @mention cannot be removed as it would break the in-reply-to-status-id semantics. Attempting to remove it will be silently ignored.

parameters.name: attachment_url
parameters.description: In order for a URL to not be counted in the status body of an extended Tweet, provide a URL as a Tweet attachment. This URL must be a Tweet permalink, or Direct Message deep link. Arbitrary, non-Twitter URLs must remain in the status text. URLs passed to the attachment_url parameter not matching either a Tweet permalink or Direct Message deep link will fail at Tweet creation and cause an exception.

parameters.name: media_ids
parameters.description: A comma-delimited list of media_ids to associate with the Tweet. You may include up to 4 photos or 1 animated GIF or 1 video in a Tweet. See Uploading Media for further details on uploading media.

parameters.name: possibly_sensitive
parameters.description: If you upload Tweet media that might be considered sensitive content such as nudity, or medical procedures, you must set this value to true. See Media setting and best practices for more context.

parameters.name: lat
parameters.description: The latitude of the location this Tweet refers to. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there is no corresponding long parameter.

parameters.name: long
parameters.description: The longitude of the location this Tweet refers to. The valid ranges for longitude are -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there no corresponding lat parameter.

parameters.name: place_id
parameters.description: A place in the world.

parameters.name: display_coordinates
parameters.description: Whether or not to put a pin on the exact coordinates a Tweet has been sent from.

parameters.name: trim_user
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , the response will include a user object including only the author’s ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

parameters.name: enable_dm_commands
parameters.description: When set to true , enables shortcode commands for sending Direct Messages as part of the status text to send a Direct Message to a user. When set to false , disables this behavior and includes any leading characters in the status text that is posted

parameters.name: fail_dm_commands
parameters.description: When set to true , causes any status text that starts with shortcode commands to return an API error. When set to false , allows shortcode commands to be sent in the status text and acted on by the API.

parameters.name: lat
parameters.description: If provided with a long parameter the available trend locations will be sorted by distance, nearest to furthest, to the co-ordinate pair. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (West is negative, East is positive) inclusive.

parameters.name: long
parameters.description: If provided with a lat parameter the available trend locations will be sorted by distance, nearest to furthest, to the co-ordinate pair. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (West is negative, East is positive) inclusive.

parameters.name: list_id
parameters.description: The numerical id of the list.

parameters.name: slug
parameters.description: You can identify a list by its slug instead of its numerical id. If you decide to do so, note that you’ll also have to specify the list owner using the owner_id or owner_screen_name parameters.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: A comma separated list of user IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: A comma separated list of screen names, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: owner_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The user ID of the user who owns the list being requested by a slug .

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The Yahoo! Where On Earth ID of the location to return trending information for. Global information is available by using 1 as the WOEID .

parameters.name: exclude
parameters.description: Setting this equal to hashtags will remove all hashtags from the trends list.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the potentially muted user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the potentially muted user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Many programming environments will not consume Twitter IDs due to their size. Provide this option to have IDs returned as strings instead. Read more about Twitter IDs .

parameters.name: cursor

Causes the list of IDs to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the potentially blocked user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the potentially blocked user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: access_token
parameters.description: The value of the bearer token to revoke.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of IDs to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: banner
parameters.description: The Base64-encoded or raw image data being uploaded as the user’s new profile banner.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the preferred section of the image being uploaded in pixels. Use with height , offset_left , and offset_top to select the desired region of the image to use.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the preferred section of the image being uploaded in pixels. Use with width , offset_left , and offset_top to select the desired region of the image to use.

parameters.name: offset_left
parameters.description: The number of pixels by which to offset the uploaded image from the left. Use with height , width , and offset_top to select the desired region of the image to use.

parameters.name: offset_top
parameters.description: The number of pixels by which to offset the uploaded image from the top. Use with height , width , and offset_left to select the desired region of the image to use.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user to unfollow.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user to unfollow.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: (optional) For paging through result sets greater than 1 page, use the “next_cursor” property from the previous request.

parameters.name: webhook_id

parameters.name: webhook_id
parameters.description: (required) Webhook ID. Defined in resource path.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: Specifies the maximum number of results to include in the response. Specify a count between 1 and 200. A next_cursor value will be provided in the response if additional results are available.

parameters.name: max_position

parameters.name: min_position

parameters.name: since_id

If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

Using exclude_replies with the count parameter will mean you will receive up-to count Tweets — this is because the count parameter retrieves that many Tweets before filtering out retweets and replies.

parameters.name: screen_name

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Enable/disable device notifications from the target user.

parameters.name: retweets
parameters.description: Enable/disable Retweets from the target user.

parameters.name: list_id

parameters.name: slug

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: Breaks the results into pages. A single page contains 20 lists. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body’s next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each tweet will include a node called “entities”. This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See Tweet Entities for more details.

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Some programming environments will not consume Twitter IDs due to their size. Provide this option to have IDs returned as strings instead. Read more about Twitter IDs . This parameter is important to use in Javascript environments.

parameters.name: trim_user
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each Tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

parameters.name: slug

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The amount of results to return per page. Defaults to 20. No more than 1000 results will ever be returned in a single page.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: Breaks the results into pages. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body’s next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list. It is recommended to always use cursors when the method supports them. See Cursoring for more information.

parameters.name: source_id
parameters.description: The user_id of the subject user.

parameters.name: source_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen_name of the subject user.

parameters.name: target_id
parameters.description: The user_id of the target user.

parameters.name: target_screen_name
parameters.description: The screen_name of the target user.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user object.

parameters.name: include_email
parameters.description: When set to true email will be returned in the user objects as a string. If the user does not have an email address on their account, or if the email address is not verified, null will be returned.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: A comma separated list of Tweet IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node that may appear within embedded statuses will not be included when set to false .

parameters.name: trim_user
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 , each Tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: When using the map parameter, Tweets that do not exist or cannot be viewed by the current user will still have their key represented but with an explicitly null value paired with it

parameters.name: include_ext_alt_text
parameters.description: If alt text has been added to any attached media entities, this parameter will return an ext_alt_text value in the top-level key for the media entity. If no value has been set, this will be returned as null

parameters.name: force_login
parameters.description: Forces the user to enter their credentials to ensure the correct users account is authorized.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: Prefills the username input box of the OAuth login screen with the given value.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name. Note: : Specifies the ID of the user to get lists from. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: Set this to true if you would like owned lists to be returned first. See description above for information on how this parameter works.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the list of connections to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: stringify_ids
parameters.description: Some programming environments will not consume Twitter IDs due to their size. Provide this option to have IDs returned as strings instead. More about Twitter IDs .

parameters.name: oauth_verifier
parameters.description: If using the OAuth web-flow, set this parameter to the value of the oauth_verifier returned in the callback URL. If you are using out-of-band OAuth, set this value to the pin-code. For OAuth 1.0a compliance this parameter is required . OAuth 1.0a is strictly enforced and applications not using the oauth_verifier will fail to complete the OAuth flow.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: (required) The id of the Direct Message event that should be returned.

parameters.name: lat
parameters.description: The latitude to search around. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn’t a corresponding long parameter.

parameters.name: long
parameters.description: The longitude to search around. The valid ranges for longitude are -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Free-form text to match against while executing a geo-based query, best suited for finding nearby locations by name. Remember to URL encode the query.

parameters.name: ip
parameters.description: An IP address. Used when attempting to fix geolocation based off of the user’s IP address.

parameters.name: granularity
parameters.description:
This is the minimal granularity of place types to return and must be one of: poi , neighborhood , city , admin or country . If no granularity is provided for the request neighborhood is assumed.

Setting this to city , for example, will find places which have a type of city , admin or country .

parameters.name: accuracy
parameters.description: A hint on the “region” in which to search. If a number, then this is a radius in meters, but it can also take a string that is suffixed with ft to specify feet. If this is not passed in, then it is assumed to be 0m . If coming from a device, in practice, this value is whatever accuracy the device has measuring its location (whether it be coming from a GPS, WiFi triangulation, etc.).

parameters.name: max_results
parameters.description: A hint as to the number of results to return. This does not guarantee that the number of results returned will equal max_results, but instead informs how many “nearby” results to return. Ideally, only pass in the number of places you intend to display to the user here.

parameters.name: contained_within
parameters.description:
This is the place_id which you would like to restrict the search results to. Setting this value means only places within the given place_id will be found.

Specify a place_id. For example, to scope all results to places within “San Francisco, CA USA”, you would specify a place_id of “5a110d312052166f”.

parameters.name: attribute:street_address
parameters.description: This parameter searches for places which have this given street address. There are other well-known, and application specific attributes available. Custom attributes are also permitted. Learn more about Place attributes .

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: The search query to run against people search.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Specifies the page of results to retrieve.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of potential user results to retrieve per page. This value has a maximum of 20.

parameters.name: include_entities
parameters.description: The entities node will not be included in embedded Tweet objects when set to false .

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user for whom to return results.

parameters.name: screen_name
parameters.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Causes the results to be broken into pages. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.”

The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of users to return per page, up to a maximum of 200.

parameters.name: skip_status
parameters.description: When set to either true , t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

parameters.name: include_user_entities
parameters.description: The user object entities node will not be included when set to false .

info: This is the information of the API
